trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure single sign-on between Azure Active Directory and Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure single sign-on between Azure Active Directory and Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source:
The objective of this tutorial is to show you how to integrate Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
Integrating Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure AD provides you with the following benefits:
trans-unit.target:
The objective of this tutorial is to show you how to integrate Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
Integrating Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure AD provides you with the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: You can control in Azure AD who has access to Amazon Web Service (AWS)
trans-unit.target: You can control in Azure AD who has access to Amazon Web Service (AWS)

trans-unit.source: You can enable your users to automatically get signed-on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) (Single Sign-On) with their Azure AD accounts
trans-unit.target: You can enable your users to automatically get signed-on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) (Single Sign-On) with their Azure AD accounts

trans-unit.source: You can manage your accounts in one central location - the Azure Active Directory Portal
trans-unit.target: You can manage your accounts in one central location - the Azure Active Directory Portal

trans-unit.source: If you want to know more details about SaaS app integration with Azure AD, see <linkText>What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to know more details about SaaS app integration with Azure AD, see <linkText>What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To configure Azure AD integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need the following items:
trans-unit.target: To configure Azure AD integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need the following items:

trans-unit.source: An Azure AD subscription
trans-unit.target: An Azure AD subscription

trans-unit.source: An Amazon Web Service (AWS) single-sign on enabled subscription
trans-unit.target: An Amazon Web Service (AWS) single-sign on enabled subscription

trans-unit.source: To test the steps in this tutorial, we do not recommend using a production environment.
trans-unit.target: To test the steps in this tutorial, we do not recommend using a production environment.

trans-unit.source: To test the steps in this tutorial, you should follow these recommendations:
trans-unit.target: To test the steps in this tutorial, you should follow these recommendations:

trans-unit.source: You should not use your production environment, unless this is necessary.
trans-unit.target: You should not use your production environment, unless this is necessary.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an Azure AD trial environment, you can get a one-month trial <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an Azure AD trial environment, you can get a one-month trial <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source:
The objective of this tutorial is to enable you to test Azure AD single sign-on in a test environment.
The scenario outlined in this tutorial consists of three main building blocks:
trans-unit.target:
The objective of this tutorial is to enable you to test Azure AD single sign-on in a test environment.
The scenario outlined in this tutorial consists of three main building blocks:

trans-unit.source: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery
trans-unit.target: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery

trans-unit.source: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on
trans-unit.target: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on

trans-unit.source: To configure the integration of Amazon Web Service (AWS) into Azure AD, you need to add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery to your list of managed SaaS apps.
trans-unit.target: To configure the integration of Amazon Web Service (AWS) into Azure AD, you need to add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery to your list of managed SaaS apps.

trans-unit.source:
In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

Active Directory
trans-unit.target:
In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

Active Directory

trans-unit.source: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.
trans-unit.target: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.

trans-unit.source:
To open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.

Applications
trans-unit.target:
To open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.

Applications

trans-unit.source:
Click Add at the bottom of the page.

Applications
trans-unit.target:
Click Add at the bottom of the page.

Applications

trans-unit.source:
On the What do you want to do dialog, click Add an application from the gallery.

Applications
trans-unit.target:
On the What do you want to do dialog, click Add an application from the gallery.

Applications

trans-unit.source:
In the search box, type Amazon Web Service (AWS).

Applications
trans-unit.target:
In the search box, type Amazon Web Service (AWS).

Applications

trans-unit.source:
In the results pane, select Amazon Web Service (AWS), and then click Complete to add the application.

Applications
trans-unit.target:
In the results pane, select Amazon Web Service (AWS), and then click Complete to add the application.

Applications

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to show you how to configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS) based on a test user called "Britta Simon".
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to show you how to configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS) based on a test user called "Britta Simon".

trans-unit.source:
For single sign-on to work, Azure AD needs to know what the counterpart user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) to an user in Azure AD is. In other words, a link relationship between an Azure AD user and the related user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) needs to be established.
This link relationship is established by assigning the value of the user name in Azure AD as the value of the Username in Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target:
For single sign-on to work, Azure AD needs to know what the counterpart user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) to an user in Azure AD is. In other words, a link relationship between an Azure AD user and the related user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) needs to be established.
This link relationship is established by assigning the value of the user name in Azure AD as the value of the Username in Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: To configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need to complete the following building blocks:
trans-unit.target: To configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need to complete the following building blocks:

trans-unit.source: [Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On](#configuring-azure-ad-single-single-sign-on) - to enable your users to use this feature.
trans-unit.target: [Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On](#configuring-azure-ad-single-single-sign-on) - to enable your users to use this feature.

trans-unit.source: [Creating an Azure AD test user](#creating-an-azure-ad-test-user) - to test Azure AD single sign-on with Britta Simon.
trans-unit.target: [Creating an Azure AD test user](#creating-an-azure-ad-test-user) - to test Azure AD single sign-on with Britta Simon.

trans-unit.source: [Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user](#creating-a-halogen-software-test-user) - to have a counterpart of Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS) that is linked to the Azure AD representation of her.
trans-unit.target: [Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user](#creating-a-halogen-software-test-user) - to have a counterpart of Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS) that is linked to the Azure AD representation of her.

trans-unit.source: [Assigning the Azure AD test user](#assigning-the-azure-ad-test-user) - to enable Britta Simon to use Azure AD single sign-on.
trans-unit.target: [Assigning the Azure AD test user](#assigning-the-azure-ad-test-user) - to enable Britta Simon to use Azure AD single sign-on.

trans-unit.source: [Testing Single Sign-On](#testing-single-sign-on) - to verify whether the configuration works.
trans-unit.target: [Testing Single Sign-On](#testing-single-sign-on) - to verify whether the configuration works.

trans-unit.source:
The objective of this section is to enable Azure AD single sign-on in the Azure AD portal and to configure single sign-on in your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
Your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application expects the SAML assertions in a specific format, which requires you to add custom attribute mappings to your saml token attributes configuration. The following screenshot shows an example for this.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
The objective of this section is to enable Azure AD single sign-on in the Azure AD portal and to configure single sign-on in your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
Your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application expects the SAML assertions in a specific format, which requires you to add custom attribute mappings to your saml token attributes configuration. The following screenshot shows an example for this.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: To configure Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To configure Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source:
In the Azure AD portal, on the Amazon Web Service (AWS) application integration page, click Configure single sign-on to open the Configure Single Sign-On dialog.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
In the Azure AD portal, on the Amazon Web Service (AWS) application integration page, click Configure single sign-on to open the Configure Single Sign-On dialog.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the How would you like users to sign on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, select Azure AD Single Sign-On, and then click Next.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the How would you like users to sign on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, select Azure AD Single Sign-On, and then click Next.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the Configure App Settings dialog page, click Next.

Configure App Settings
trans-unit.target:
On the Configure App Settings dialog page, click Next.

Configure App Settings

trans-unit.source:
On the Configure single sign-on at Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, click Download metadata, and then save the metadata file locally on your computer.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Configure single sign-on at Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, click Download metadata, and then save the metadata file locally on your computer.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In a different browser window, sign-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.
trans-unit.target: In a different browser window, sign-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.

trans-unit.source:
Click Console Home.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click Console Home.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
Click Identity and Access Management.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click Identity and Access Management.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
Click Identity Providers, and then click Create Provider.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click Identity Providers, and then click Create Provider.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the Configure Provider dialog page, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Configure Provider dialog page, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: As Provider Type, select SAML.
trans-unit.target: As Provider Type, select SAML.

trans-unit.source: In the Provider Name textbox, type a provider name (e.g.: WAAD).
trans-unit.target: In the Provider Name textbox, type a provider name (e.g.: WAAD).

trans-unit.source: To upload your downloaded metadata file, click Choose File.
trans-unit.target: To upload your downloaded metadata file, click Choose File.

trans-unit.source: Click Next Step.
trans-unit.target: Click Next Step.

trans-unit.source:
On the Verify Provider Information dialog page, click Create.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Verify Provider Information dialog page, click Create.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
Go to Roles > Create New Role.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Go to Roles > Create New Role.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the Set Role Name dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On 12.1. In the Role Name textbox, type a role name (e.g.: TestUser).
trans-unit.target:
On the Set Role Name dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On 12.1. In the Role Name textbox, type a role name (e.g.: TestUser).

trans-unit.source: Click Next Step.
trans-unit.target: Click Next Step.

trans-unit.source:
On the Select Role Type dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Select Role Type dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Select Role For Identity Provider Access.
trans-unit.target: Select Role For Identity Provider Access.

trans-unit.source: In the Grant Web Single Sign-On (WebSSO) access to SAML providers section, click Select.
trans-unit.target: In the Grant Web Single Sign-On (WebSSO) access to SAML providers section, click Select.

trans-unit.source:
On the Establish Trust dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On 14.1. As SAML provider, select the SAML provider you have created previousley (e.g.: WAAD)
trans-unit.target:
On the Establish Trust dialog, perform the following steps:

Configure Single Sign-On 14.1. As SAML provider, select the SAML provider you have created previousley (e.g.: WAAD)

trans-unit.source:
On the Azure AD portal, select the single sign-on configuration confirmation, and then click Next.

What is Azure AD Connect
trans-unit.target:
On the Azure AD portal, select the single sign-on configuration confirmation, and then click Next.

What is Azure AD Connect

trans-unit.source:
On the Single sign-on confirmation page, click Complete to close the Configure single sign-on dialog.

What is Azure AD Connect
trans-unit.target:
On the Single sign-on confirmation page, click Complete to close the Configure single sign-on dialog.

What is Azure AD Connect

trans-unit.source:
In the menu on the top, click Attributes to open the SAML Token Attributes dialog.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
In the menu on the top, click Attributes to open the SAML Token Attributes dialog.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
Click add user attribute.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click add user attribute.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/Role.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/Role.

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Value textbox, type arn:aws:iam::214510765665:role/Admin,arn:aws:iam::214510765665:saml-provider/WAAD.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Value textbox, type arn:aws:iam::214510765665:role/Admin,arn:aws:iam::214510765665:saml-provider/WAAD.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.

trans-unit.source:
Click add user attribute.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click add user attribute.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/RoleSessionName.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/RoleSessionName.

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Value list, select user:mail.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Value list, select user:mail.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.

trans-unit.source:
Click Apply Changes.

Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target:
Click Apply Changes.

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source:
The objective of this section is to create a test user in the Azure portal called Britta Simon.
In the Users list, select Britta Simon.
Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target:
The objective of this section is to create a test user in the Azure portal called Britta Simon.
In the Users list, select Britta Simon.
Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source:
In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.

To display the list of users, in the menu on the top, click Users.

To open the Add User dialog, in the toolbar on the bottom, click Add User.

trans-unit.source:
On the Tell us about this user dialog page, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: As Type Of User, select New user in your organization.
trans-unit.target: As Type Of User, select New user in your organization.

trans-unit.source: In the User Name textbox, type BrittaSimon.
trans-unit.target: In the User Name textbox, type BrittaSimon.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source:
On the User Profile dialog page, perform the following steps:
Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target:
On the User Profile dialog page, perform the following steps:
Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: In the First Name textbox, type Britta.
trans-unit.target: In the First Name textbox, type Britta.

trans-unit.source: In the Last Name txtbox, type, Simon.
trans-unit.target: In the Last Name txtbox, type, Simon.

trans-unit.source: In the Display Name textbox, type Britta Simon.
trans-unit.target: In the Display Name textbox, type Britta Simon.

trans-unit.source: In the Role list, select User.
trans-unit.target: In the Role list, select User.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source:
On the Get temporary password dialog page, click create.
Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target:
On the Get temporary password dialog page, click create.
Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source:
On the Get temporary password dialog page, perform the following steps:
Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target:
On the Get temporary password dialog page, perform the following steps:
Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: Write down the value of the New Password.
trans-unit.target: Write down the value of the New Password.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete.

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.

trans-unit.source:
Click the Console Home icon.

Configure Single Sign-On

Click Identity and Access Management.

Configure Single Sign-On

In the Dashboard, click Users, and then click Create New Users.

Configure Single Sign-On

In the Dashboard, click Users, and then click Create New Users.

On the Create User dialog, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.target:

Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In the Enter User Names textboxes, type Brita Simon's user name in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: In the Enter User Names textboxes, type Brita Simon's user name in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source:

trans-unit.source:
The objective of this section is to test your Azure AD single sign-on configuration using the Access Panel.
When you click the Amazon Web Service (AWS) tile in the Access Panel, you should get automatically signed-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
trans-unit.target:
The objective of this section is to test your Azure AD single sign-on configuration using the Access Panel.
When you click the Amazon Web Service (AWS) tile in the Access Panel, you should get automatically signed-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
